Miso-Butter Roast Chicken With Acorn Squash Panzanella

    "ingredients": [
        '1 (3½–4-lb.) whole chicken', '2¾ tsp. kosher salt, divided, plus more',
        '2 small acorn squash (about 3 lb. total)', '2 Tbsp. finely chopped sage',
        '1 Tbsp. finely chopped rosemary', '6 Tbsp. unsalted butter, melted, plus 3 Tbsp. room temperature',
        '¼ tsp. ground allspice', 'Pinch of crushed red pepper flakes', 'Freshly ground black pepper',
        '⅓ loaf good-quality sturdy white bread, torn into 1" pieces (about 2½ cups)',
        '2 medium apples (such as Gala or Pink Lady; about 14 oz. total), cored, cut into 1" pieces',
        '2 Tbsp. extra-virgin olive oil', '½ small red onion, thinly sliced',
        '3 Tbsp. apple cider vinegar', '1 Tbsp. white miso', '¼ cup all-purpose flour',
        '2 Tbsp. unsalted butter, room temperature', '¼ cup dry white wine',
        '2 cups unsalted chicken broth', '2 tsp. white miso', 'Kosher salt, freshly ground pepper'
    ],
    "instructions":
        1. Pat chicken dry with paper towels, season all over with 2 tsp. salt, and tie legs together with kitchen twine. Let sit at room temperature 1 hour.

        2. Meanwhile, halve squash and scoop out seeds. Run a vegetable peeler along ridges of squash halves to remove skin. Cut each half into ½""-thick wedges; arrange on a rimmed baking sheet.

        3. Combine sage, rosemary, and 6 Tbsp. melted butter in a large bowl; pour half of mixture over squash on baking sheet. Sprinkle squash with allspice, red pepper flakes, and ½ tsp. salt and season with black pepper; toss to coat.

        4. Add bread, apples, oil, and ¼ tsp. salt to remaining herb butter in bowl; season with black pepper and toss to combine. Set aside.
        Place onion and vinegar in a small bowl; season with salt and toss to coat. Let sit, tossing occasionally, until ready to serve.

        5. Place a rack in middle and lower third of oven; preheat to 425°F. Mix miso and 3 Tbsp. room-temperature butter in a small bowl until smooth. Pat chicken dry with paper towels, then rub or brush all over with miso butter. Place chicken in a large cast-iron skillet and roast on middle rack until an instant-read thermometer inserted into the thickest part of breast registers 155°F, 50–60 minutes. (Temperature will climb to 165°F while chicken rests.) Let chicken rest in skillet at least 5 minutes, then transfer to a plate; reserve skillet.

        6. Meanwhile, roast squash on lower rack until  mostly tender, about 25 minutes. Remove from oven and scatter reserved bread mixture over, spreading into as even a layer as you can manage. Return to oven and roast until bread is golden brown and crisp and apples are tender, about 15 minutes. Remove from oven, drain pickled onions, and toss to combine. Transfer to a serving dish.

        7. Using your fingers, mash flour and butter in a small bowl to combine.

        8. Set reserved skillet with chicken drippings over medium heat. You should have about ¼ cup, but a little over or under is all good. (If you have significantly more, drain off and set excess aside.) Add wine and cook, stirring often and scraping up any browned bits with a wooden spoon, until bits are loosened and wine is reduced by about half (you should be able to smell the wine), about 2 minutes. Add butter mixture; cook, stirring often, until a smooth paste forms, about 2 minutes. Add broth and any reserved drippings and cook, stirring constantly, until combined and thickened, 6–8 minutes. Remove from heat and stir in miso. Taste and season with salt and black pepper.

        9. Serve chicken with gravy and squash panzanella alongside.
------------------------------
Please recall all the ingredients before continuing.

Great choice! The recipe you want to prepare is Miso-Butter Roast Chicken With Acorn Squash Panzanella. Here are all the ingredients you will need:

- 1 (3½–4-lb.) whole chicken
- 2¾ tsp. kosher salt, divided, plus more
- 2 small acorn squash (about 3 lb. total)
- 2 Tbsp. finely chopped sage
- 1 Tbsp. finely chopped rosemary
- 6 Tbsp. unsalted butter, melted, plus 3 Tbsp. room temperature
- ¼ tsp. ground allspice
- Pinch of crushed red pepper flakes
- Freshly ground black pepper
- ⅓ loaf good-quality sturdy white bread, torn into 1" pieces (about 2½ cups)
- 2 medium apples (such as Gala or Pink Lady; about 14 oz. total), cored, cut into 1" pieces
- 2 Tbsp. extra-virgin olive oil
- ½ small red onion, thinly sliced
- 3 Tbsp. apple cider vinegar
- 1 Tbsp. white miso
- ¼ cup all-purpose flour
- 2 Tbsp. unsalted butter, room temperature
- ¼ cup dry white wine
- 2 cups unsalted chicken broth
- 2 tsp. white miso
- Kosher salt, freshly ground pepper

In this step, you will prepare the whole chicken for roasting. Here's a detailed explanation:

1. Pat the chicken dry with paper towels: This helps to remove any excess moisture on the chicken's surface, which can help achieve a crispy skin when roasted.

2. Season all over with 2 tsp. salt: Sprinkle salt evenly over the chicken, making sure to season the entire surface. This step helps to enhance the flavor of the chicken.

3. Tie legs together with kitchen twine: Tying the legs together helps the chicken cook evenly and keeps its shape during roasting.

4. Let the seasoned chicken sit at room temperature for 1 hour: Allowing the chicken to come to room temperature before roasting helps it cook more evenly and ensures a juicier end result.

Once you have completed these steps, please let me know if you have any questions or if you're ready to move on to the next step by saying 'next'.
can i use a different type of seasoning instead of salt for the chicken?

Yes, you can definitely customize the seasoning for the chicken based on your preferences. If you'd like to use a different type of seasoning instead of salt, you can experiment with herbs, spices, or seasoning blends that you enjoy. Just make sure to adjust the quantity according to your taste preferences and the flavor profile you want to achieve. Feel free to get creative with your seasonings to add a unique touch to the dish.

Once you've decided on your seasoning choice and applied it to the chicken, please let me know when you're ready to move on to the next step by saying 'next'.

In this step, you will be preparing the acorn squash for roasting. Here's a breakdown of the process:

1. Halve the squash and scoop out the seeds: Cut the acorn squash in half lengthwise and use a spoon to scoop out the seeds and stringy pulp from the center of each half.

2. Remove the skin with a vegetable peeler: Use a vegetable peeler to remove the skin from the squash halves. Make sure to peel along the ridges of the squash to get rid of the tough outer skin.

3. Cut each half into ½""-thick wedges: Once the skin is removed, slice each squash half into ½-inch thick wedges. This will help the squash cook evenly and caramelize nicely in the oven.

4. Arrange the squash wedges on a rimmed baking sheet: Place the prepared squash wedges on a baking sheet with raised edges to catch any juices that may release during roasting.

After you have completed these steps, please let me know if you have any questions or if you're ready to proceed to the next step by saying 'next'.
can i use a paring knife instead of a vegetable peeler to remove the skin from the acorn squash?

Yes, you can use a paring knife as an alternative to a vegetable peeler to remove the skin from the acorn squash. When using a paring knife, make sure to carefully peel the skin, following the ridges of the squash to remove the tough outer layer effectively. Take your time and work slowly to avoid any accidents while peeling the squash with a paring knife.

Once you've peeled the acorn squash using a paring knife or your preferred method, please let me know if you have any more questions or when you're ready to move on to the next step by saying 'next'.
next

In this step, you will be creating a flavorful herb butter mixture to coat the acorn squash before roasting. Here's a detailed explanation of the process:

1. Combine chopped sage, chopped rosemary, and 6 tablespoons of melted butter in a large bowl: Mix the finely chopped sage, finely chopped rosemary, and melted butter together until well combined. This herb butter mixture will infuse the squash with fragrant flavors during roasting.

2. Pour half of the herb butter mixture over the prepared acorn squash on the baking sheet: Drizzle half of the herb butter mixture evenly over the squash wedges, ensuring they are well coated with the herb-infused butter.

3. Sprinkle the squash with ground allspice, crushed red pepper flakes, ½ teaspoon of salt, and black pepper: Evenly distribute the allspice, red pepper flakes, salt, and black pepper over the squash wedges to season them with a warm, spicy, and aromatic blend of flavors.

4. Toss the squash to coat: Gently toss the seasoned squash wedges on the baking sheet to ensure they are evenly coated with the herb butter mixture and seasonings, allowing the flavors to meld together.

Once you have completed these steps and tossed the squash to coat, please let me know if you have any questions or if you're ready to proceed to the next step by saying 'next'.
can i use dried herbs instead of fresh for the herb butter mixture?

Yes, you can definitely use dried herbs as a substitute for fresh herbs in the herb butter mixture. When using dried herbs, keep in mind that they are more concentrated in flavor than fresh herbs, so you may need to adjust the quantities accordingly. As a general rule of thumb, you can use about one-third to half the amount of dried herbs compared to fresh herbs called for in a recipe.

Feel free to use your favorite dried herbs or a combination of dried herbs that you enjoy to create the herb butter mixture for the acorn squash. Once you've made any adjustments and seasoned the squash, please let me know when you're ready to proceed by saying 'next'.
next

In this step, you will be preparing the bread and apple mixture as well as pickling the onions to serve alongside the roast chicken and acorn squash panzanella. Here's a detailed breakdown of the process:

1. Add torn bread pieces, chopped apples, olive oil, and ¼ teaspoon of salt to the remaining herb butter mixture in the bowl: Combine the torn pieces of sturdy white bread, chopped apples, olive oil, and salt with the remaining herb butter mixture. Make sure the bread and apples are coated evenly with the herb-infused butter for added flavor.

2. Season with black pepper and toss to combine: Sprinkle black pepper over the bread and apple mixture, then toss everything together until well-combined. The black pepper adds a bit of warmth and depth to the dish.

3. Set the bread and apple mixture aside: Once the bread and apple mixture is thoroughly combined, set it aside to allow the flavors to meld together while you prepare the rest of the meal.

4. Place thinly sliced red onion and apple cider vinegar in a small bowl: Combine the sliced red onion and apple cider vinegar in a separate bowl. Season the mixture with salt and toss to coat the onions with the vinegar.

5. Let the pickled onions sit, tossing occasionally, until ready to serve: Allow the pickled onions to marinate in the vinegar, tossing them occasionally to ensure they are evenly coated and pickled. The pickled onions will add a tangy and refreshing element to the dish when served.

Once you have completed these steps and prepared the bread and apple mixture along with the pickled onions, please let me know if you have any questions or if you're ready to move on to the next step by saying 'next'.
can i use a different type of vinegar instead of apple cider vinegar for pickling the onions?

Yes, you can definitely use a different type of vinegar as a substitute for apple cider vinegar when pickling onions. Some alternatives to apple cider vinegar include white vinegar, red wine vinegar, balsamic vinegar, or sherry vinegar. Each type of vinegar will impart a slightly different flavor profile to the pickled onions, so choose one based on your preference and the overall taste you want to achieve in the dish.

Feel free to use your preferred vinegar choice for pickling the onions to add a unique twist to the dish. Once you've decided on the vinegar to use or if you have any more questions, please let me know when you're ready to move on by saying 'next'.
next

In this step, you will be preparing and roasting the miso-butter-coated chicken in the oven. Here's a detailed explanation of the process:

1. Preheat the oven: Place racks in the middle and lower thirds of the oven and preheat to 425°F (218°C). Preheating ensures that the oven reaches the desired temperature for roasting the chicken.

2. Prepare the miso butter mixture: In a small bowl, mix the white miso paste and 3 tablespoons of room-temperature butter until smooth. This flavorful miso butter mixture will add depth and umami to the roasted chicken.

3. Pat the chicken dry: Use paper towels to pat the seasoned chicken dry, removing any excess moisture. A dry surface helps the skin crisp up during roasting.

4. Coat the chicken with miso butter: Rub or brush the miso butter mixture all over the chicken, ensuring it is evenly coated with the flavorful mixture. This step adds richness and savory notes to the roasted chicken.

5. Roast the chicken: Place the miso-butter-coated chicken in a large cast-iron skillet and roast it on the middle rack of the preheated oven. Roast until an instant-read thermometer inserted into the thickest part of the chicken breast registers 155°F (68°C), which typically takes about 50-60 minutes. The internal temperature will continue to rise to 165°F (74°C) as the chicken rests.

6. Rest the chicken: Allow the roasted chicken to rest in the skillet for at least 5 minutes. Resting helps the juices redistribute, resulting in a juicier and more tender chicken. After resting, transfer the chicken to a plate and reserve the skillet for making gravy.

Once you have completed these steps and the chicken is roasted and resting, please let me know if you have any questions or if you're ready to proceed by saying 'next'.
can i use a different type of butter for the miso butter mixture, such as vegan butter or ghee?

Yes, you can definitely use a different type of butter for the miso butter mixture if you prefer. Vegan butter or ghee can be suitable substitutes for traditional butter in the miso butter mixture. Vegan butter is a dairy-free option made from plant-based oils, while ghee is clarified butter commonly used in Indian cuisine.

When using a different type of butter, consider the flavor profile and characteristics of the substitute butter, as they may impact the overall taste of the dish. Adjust the quantity and seasoning to suit your preferences and dietary needs. Once you've decided on the type of butter to use, please let me know if you have any more questions or if you're ready to move on by saying 'next'.
next

In this step, you will be completing the roasting of the acorn squash and bread mixture to create the delicious panzanella side dish. Here's a detailed explanation of the process:

1. Roast the squash: Continue roasting the acorn squash on the lower rack of the oven until it is mostly tender, which typically takes about 25 minutes. Roasting the squash helps to enhance its natural sweetness and texture.

2. Add the bread mixture: Remove the partially roasted squash from the oven and scatter the reserved bread and apple mixture over the squash on the baking sheet. Spread the mixture into an even layer to ensure even roasting and caramelization of the bread and apples.

3. Return to the oven: Place the baking sheet back into the oven and roast the panzanella until the bread is golden brown and crisp, and the apples are tender, which usually takes about 15 minutes. This step allows the flavors to meld together, creating a delicious and crunchy texture.

4. Remove from the oven: Once the bread is golden brown, crisp, and the apples are tender, remove the panzanella from the oven. Drain the pickled onions that you prepared earlier and toss them with the roasted squash and bread mixture to combine all the elements.

5. Transfer to a serving dish: Transfer the finished panzanella, a flavorful combination of roasted squash, bread, apples, and pickled onions, to a serving dish. The panzanella side dish is now ready to be served alongside the miso-butter roast chicken.

Once you have completed these steps and prepared the panzanella, please let me know if you have any questions or if you're ready to proceed by saying 'next'.
what can i use as a substitute for acorn squash in this recipe?

If you're looking for a substitute for acorn squash in this recipe, you can consider using other types of winter squash that have a similar texture and flavor profile. Some suitable alternatives to acorn squash include:

- Butternut squash: Butternut squash has a sweet and nutty flavor, similar to acorn squash, and can be roasted or used in the panzanella dish as a replacement.
- Delicata squash: Delicata squash has a creamy texture and a mild, sweet flavor that works well in roasting dishes.
- Kabocha squash: Kabocha squash has a sweet and slightly nutty flavor, making it a delicious substitute for acorn squash.

These alternatives can be used in place of acorn squash in the recipe to create a flavorful and comforting dish. Feel free to choose the winter squash variety that you enjoy and that complements the other ingredients in the recipe. If you have any more questions or when you're ready, please let me know by saying 'next'.
next

In this step, you will be creating a smooth paste by mashing together flour and butter in a small bowl. Here's a detailed explanation of the process:

1. Take a small bowl: Begin by selecting a small bowl to mash and combine the flour and butter. The bowl should be large enough to comfortably mix the ingredients without spillage.

2. Add the flour and butter: Place the specified amount of all-purpose flour and room-temperature unsalted butter in the bowl. The butter should be soft enough to easily mix with the flour.

3. Mash and combine: Using your fingers, gently mash and mix the flour and butter together until they form a smooth paste-like consistency. Continue blending the ingredients until the flour is fully incorporated into the butter, creating a thick and uniform mixture.

4. Ensure a smooth texture: Aim to achieve a homogeneous mixture without any lumps or dry flour pockets. The final paste should be smooth, without any visible traces of unmixed flour.

This flour and butter paste will be used later in the recipe to thicken and enrich the gravy for serving with the roast chicken. Once you have successfully combined the flour and butter, please let me know if you have any questions or when you're ready to proceed by saying 'next'.
can i use margarine instead of butter for this step?

Yes, you can use margarine as a substitute for butter in this step. Margarine is a suitable alternative to butter in many recipes, including creating a flour and margarine paste for thickening sauces or gravies. When using margarine, ensure it is at room temperature or slightly softened to easily mix with the flour and create a smooth paste.

Feel free to use margarine in place of butter for this step to achieve a similar thickening effect in the gravy. If you have any more questions or when you're ready to move on, please let me know by saying 'next'.
next

In this step, you will be creating a flavorful gravy using the drippings from the roasted chicken. Here's a detailed explanation of the process:

1. Set the reserved skillet with chicken drippings over medium heat: Place the skillet containing the drippings from the roasted chicken over medium heat on the stovetop. The drippings will add rich flavor to the gravy.

2. Add wine and deglaze the skillet: Pour the wine into the skillet with the drippings and cook, stirring often and scraping up any browned bits from the bottom of the skillet with a wooden spoon. This process, known as deglazing, helps incorporate the flavorful bits into the gravy.

3. Reduce the wine: Cook the wine until it is reduced by about half, which usually takes around 2 minutes. The reduction process concentrates the flavors and allows the alcohol to cook off.

4. Add the flour and butter mixture: Once the wine is reduced, add the flour and butter mixture to the skillet. Stir often and cook until a smooth paste forms, which typically takes about 2 minutes. This mixture will help thicken the gravy.

5. Incorporate the broth and reserved drippings: Pour in the unsalted chicken broth and any additional reserved drippings from the roasted chicken. Stir constantly and cook until the ingredients are combined and the gravy is thickened, which usually takes 6-8 minutes.

6. Stir in miso: Once the gravy is thickened, remove the skillet from the heat and stir in the white miso paste. The miso will add depth and umami flavor to the gravy.

7. Taste and season: Before serving, taste the gravy and adjust the seasoning if needed. Add salt and black pepper to taste for a well-balanced flavor.

Once you have completed these steps and prepared the miso-infused gravy, please let me know if you have any questions or when you're ready to proceed by saying 'next'.
can i use vegetable broth instead of chicken broth for this gravy?

Yes, you can definitely use vegetable broth as a substitute for chicken broth in the gravy. Vegetable broth will provide a flavorful base for the gravy and complement the other ingredients in the dish. The vegetable broth will add its own unique taste to the gravy, so feel free to use it as a vegetarian-friendly option or based on your preference.

When using vegetable broth, make sure to adjust the seasoning as needed to balance the flavors in the gravy. Once you've decided to use vegetable broth or if you have any additional questions, please let me know when you're ready to continue by saying 'next'.

In this final step, you will bring together all the components of the meal and serve the Miso-Butter Roast Chicken with Acorn Squash Panzanella. Here's a detailed explanation of how to complete the dish:

1. Serve the roast chicken: Place the roasted miso-butter-coated chicken on a serving platter or individual plates. The chicken should be moist, flavorful, and perfectly cooked to be enjoyed as the main protein in the meal.

2. Ladle the miso-infused gravy: Spoon the rich and savory miso-infused gravy over the roast chicken. The flavorful gravy adds moisture and enhances the taste of the chicken, creating a delicious pairing.

3. Serve the squash panzanella: Transfer the roasted acorn squash panzanella, a combination of squash, bread, apples, and pickled onions, to a separate serving dish. The panzanella offers a delightful contrast of textures and flavors to complement the roast chicken.

4. Garnish and present: If desired, you can garnish the dish with additional fresh herbs, such as chopped parsley or chives, for a pop of color and freshness. Present the plated or family-style meal to showcase the beautiful and delicious components of the dish.

5. Enjoy the meal: Invite your guests or family to savor the Miso-Butter Roast Chicken with Acorn Squash Panzanella and enjoy the flavors, textures, and aromas of this comforting and flavorful dish.

Once you have served the dish and are ready to enjoy your meal, please let me know if you have any questions or if you would like any final advice before completing the recipe.
what can i use as a substitute for acorn squash in the panzanella dish?

If you're looking for a substitute for acorn squash in the panzanella dish, you can consider using other types of winter squash or root vegetables that have a similar texture and flavor profile. Some alternatives to acorn squash in the panzanella dish include:

- Butternut squash: Butternut squash can be a great substitute with its sweet and nutty flavor that complements the other ingredients in the panzanella.
- Delicata squash: Delicata squash has a creamy texture and mild flavor that works well in roasting dishes and salads like panzanella.
- Sweet potatoes: Roasted sweet potatoes can add a natural sweetness and vibrant color to the panzanella, serving as a flavorful alternative to acorn squash.

Feel free to choose a winter squash or root vegetable that you enjoy and that pairs well with the bread, apples, and pickled onions in the panzanella dish. Once you've selected your substitute ingredient or if you have any more questions, please let me know by saying 'next'.
